Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Benjamin D. Zinszer of Pennsylvania State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Special brain processes in bilinguals for categorizing objects and sounds," during the summer of 2012 at Beijing Normal University in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Professor Hua Shu.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is a step towards the consolidation of first and second language learning as well as cross-language transfer under a unified developmental model. Differences in categorical representation of phonology and semantics have been widely observed between languages, necessitating a coherent explanation for the resolution of these conflicts in bilinguals. The results promise to benefit language educators with an improved understanding of the underlying challenges and learning processes that learners undergo throughout language learning. This study includes a diverse sample of participants, across ages and language histories in China, and provides an opportunity to extend this research to under-represented populations of Chinese-English bilinguals in the United States.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Categorization is an important cognitive process for proficient language use. While the environment offers an infinite variation of objects, experiences and sensations, human observers must sort this highly diverse set of information into more useful groups. For example, speakers of English use just a few words like cup, mug, and glass to describe an enormous variety of drinking vessels. Similarly, there are as many ways to pronounce a single phonemic unit (like the sound /b/ as in big) as there are people who say it. A listener must go beyond individual variation in the properties of an object or a sound to understand its purpose or meaning.

This study set out to understand the brain processes supporting categorization by examining the regions of the cerebral cortex which are active when making judgments about objects and sounds. Previous research has highlighted the left middle temporal gyrus as important in categorizing lexical tones in Chinese (Xi, Zhang, Shu, Zhang, & Li, 2010; Zhang, Xi, Xu, Shu, Wang, Li, 2011) and comparing semantic relationships between words in English (Blumenfeld, Booth, Burman, 2006). Current theories of language processing have not yet explained why the two tasks of phonological (lexical tone) and semantic categorization might require such a shared resource. We proposed that these tasks may be related by their dependence on linguistic categories, that is, categorization that is necessary for producing or comprehending a word.

In order to test this hypothesis, we used functional near-infrared spectroscopy to measure brain activity in participants while they judged which categories certain words and objects belonged in. If our hypothesis that these tasks share a dependence on a lexical categorization mechanism is true, then both tasks would elicit activity in a shared region of the brain, specifically for comparisons between different categories. Further, since prior studies have shown that the left middle temporal gyrus shows such a response in related tasks, we expected it to be increasingly active in when comparing different categories of lexical tone and objects as compared to tones or objects which belong in the same category.

Under the EAPSI grant, we collected brain imaging and behavioral data from 30 Chinese monolinguals in Beijing, China while they compared within- and between-category lexical tones and objects. Our current findings suggest that the hypothesized region (left middle temporal gyrus) is active in both tasks, but the comparison of this activity for different types of category relationship is still being analyzed. Further, behavioral data (Ameel, Malt, & Storms, 2008; Pavlenko & Malt, 2011) has shown that language learners show significant changes in their categorization as they become more proficient in a language. We expect to compare Chinese-English bilinguals to this set of monolinguals and find a similar pattern of change in their brains' responses as they become more sensitive to new categories in their second language.

At this stage, the grant has allowed us to compare two types of categorization task in Chinese monolinguals and lay a foundation for comparison with Chinese-English bilinguals at various levels of language proficiency.
